Response: No problem

Intent: I need help fast
Response: Hello, how can I help?

Intent: I don't know what are uterine polyps. Can you please tell me what are they?
Response: Have you been noticing irregular vaginal bleeding? This might be because of uterine polyps. Uterine polyps, also called endometrial polyps, are abnormal growths on the inside lining of the uterus the endometrium. Uterine polyps are very common. They occur most commonly leading up to and after menopause, your nani might know someone. Small polyps may cause no symptoms at all and can go away on their own. In other cases, untreated polyps may cause symptoms that affect quality of life and can carry a small chance of becoming cancerous. They may also affect fertility, but research on this topic is still lacking.Nearly all symptoms of uterine polyps are easy to track. Finding out early and early treatment can reduce the risk of complications.

Intent: Why do uterine polyps happen?
Response: Uterine polyps occur when cells of the uterine lining the endometrium multiply too many times, leading to lumps. These lumps often resemble hanging sacs or mushrooms made of tissue. Most are very small, but can range in size from a few millimeters, to several centimeters in diameter. Polyps can be numerous or few, and some people might only have one. To give you some more information, some people are more likely than others to develop uterine polyps. They are most common in people who are perimenopausal and postmenopausal. If you are obese, you must also know that obesity also makes people significantly more likely to develop polyps. If you have taken the the breast cancer drug tamoxifen, this can be a contributing factor too.

Intent: Are uterine polyps and uterine fibroids similar or different?
Response: Uterine polyps are similar to a type of uterine fibroids they form from muscle tissue in the uterus, but can cause many of the same symptoms, as well as other ones.  The biggest difference is that fibroids are more likely to be problematic in the reproductive years and shrink after menopause, while polyps are more likely to be problematic after menopause, so really depends on what phase you are in at the moment.

Intent: Do I need to get my uterine polyps checked out?
Response: Small uterine polyps are often asymptomatic, and can come and go on their own. Some untreated polyps, however, may cause symptoms that affect your quality of life and can lead to complications such as anemia a condition when the body doesnt have enough healthy red blood cells to function properly. This can happen when uterine polyps cause a high amount of blood loss.In rare cases, some uterine polyps carry a small chance of becoming cancerous. They may also affect the ability to get or stay pregnant, but research on this topic is still lacking

Intent: Oh I did not know that
Response: Feel free to ask me any more questions you have.

Intent: How will I be diagnosed if I have uterine polyps?
Response: When you go in for your polyp diagnosis, a healthcare provider will probably ask you questions about symptoms, medical and menstrual history and perform a simple physical exam. If they suspect you have uterine polyps, they may also perform a transvaginal ultrasound, a hysteroscopy a small camera inserted into the uterus or a biopsy a small tool is inserted into the uterus to take a tissue sample

Intent: What can I do if I have been diagnosed with uterine polyps?
Response: Small uterine polyps can go away on their own without treatment. However, if you have an uterine polyp and belive it to be problematic, then there are a few different options treating existing polyps, and for preventing their future formation, including medications, noninvasive surgery and lifestyle changes

Intent: Can I use medication for uterine polyps?
Response: Yes. Hormonal medications are sometimes prescribed to treat the symptoms of uterine polyps. These include Gonadotropin Releasing Hormone GnRH agonists, which block the bodys production of certain hormones progesterone, and progesterone, often prescribed in the form of a cream. However, there has been little research on the effectiveness of these hormonal treatments for uterine polyps.

Intent: Do I need a surgery if I have been diagnosed with uterine polyps?
Response: Small polyps can be removed with a process called hysteroscopic excision. Research says about 7 in 10 people with small polyps 1cm found their symptoms significantly improved after this procedure. Please ask your healthcare provider if you require it or not

Intent: Any connection between lifestyle changes and uterine polyps?
Response: Research on this is still unclear, but weight loss may improve the prognosis of people who are diagnosed with both uterine polyps and obesity

Intent: Will my son have a vagina like myself
Response: Alongside uterus and ovaries, men do not have a vagina. Instead, men have a penis it is the male organ used for urination and sexual intercourse.

Intent: Do my husband get periods and can he give birth to a child?
Response: Anyone who has a uterus and ovaries could become pregnant and give birth. Since men do not have either of these, they cannot give birth to a man

Intent: My vagina has an odor, is that normal?
Response: Yes, it is absolutely fine to have an odor. No vagina is odorless, nor should they be. Vaginas have many possible smells, from coppery to sweet. The smell of your vagina might change depending on your diet and menstrual cycle.If the smell is pungent and unpleasant, contact a doctor or other healthcare provider. Certain conditions, such as bacterial vaginosis, can cause your vagina to smell strongly. Your provider can advise you on any next steps.
